node.contents: It is similar to `/ Math.pow(2, shift)` except its is "unsigned" which means negative numbers are treated as large positive numbers.

astNode.text: It is similar to `/ Math.pow(2, shift)` except its is "unsigned" which means negative numbers are treated as large positive numbers.

node.contents: @OfirAttia That would start at the bottom, you need to start at the top.

astNode.text: @OfirAttia That would start at the bottom, you need to start at the top.

node.contents: Instead of starting at the bottom bit, you can start at the top bit.

astNode.text: Instead of starting at the bottom bit, you can start at the top bit.

elements.contents: int i = 35; // find where the top bit is. int shift = 0; while (i >>> (shift + 1) > 0) shift++; // print from the top bit down while (shift >= 0) System.out.print((i >>> shift--) & 1);

comments.text: // find where the top bit is. int shift = 0; while (i >>> (shift + 1) > 0) shift++; // print from the top bit down while (shift >= 0) System.out.print((i >>> shift--) & 1);

units.rawText: int i = 35; // find where the top bit is. int shift = 0; while (i >>> (shift + 1) > 0) shift++; // print from the top bit down while (shift >= 0) System.out.print((i >>> shift--) & 1);

node.contents: Numbers are really right-to-left (guess why they call it 'Arabic numerals'?). The least significant digit of a number is its last digit.

astNode.text: Numbers are really right-to-left (guess why they call it 'Arabic numerals'?). The least significant digit of a number is its last digit.

node.contents: You generate binary digits from least significant to most significant. You have to store them and then print in reverse order, from most significant to least significant.

astNode.text: You generate binary digits from least significant to most significant. You have to store them and then print in reverse order, from most significant to least significant.

node.contents: Try using a List<Integer> or an int[] for this.

astNode.text: Try using a List<Integer> or an int[] for this.

node.contents: One work around could be as below:

astNode.text: One work around could be as below:

elements.contents: int indx = 0; if(num<0){ indx =31; num = Integer.MAX_VALUE+num+2; }else{ while((int)Math.pow(2, indx) <= num){ indx++; } indx--;//get the highest index } System.out.print(""+1);//print the highest bit num = num % (int)Math.pow(2, indx); indx--; //print the bits right to left for(int i = indx; i >=0; i--){ if(Math.abs(num)<2){ System.out.print(""+num); }else if((int)Math.pow(2, i) >= num){ System.out.print(""+0); }else{ num = num % (int)Math.pow(2, i); //get the remaining value System.out.print(""+1); } }

comments.text: //get the highest index } System.out.print(""+1);//print the highest bit num = num % (int)Math.pow(2, indx); indx--; //print the bits right to left for(int i = indx; i >=0; i--){ if(Math.abs(num)<2){ System.out.print(""+num); }else if((int)Math.pow(2, i) >= num){ System.out.print(""+0); }else{ num = num % (int)Math.pow(2, i); //get the remaining value System.out.print(""+1); } }

node.contents: `place` represents the location where each binary digit is stored in the output. for the first iteration it is stored in the one's place (`place ==1`). the second digit is stored in the ten's place (`place == 10`). the third is stored in the hundreds place (`place == 100`). ect..

astNode.text: `place` represents the location where each binary digit is stored in the output. for the first iteration it is stored in the one's place (`place ==1`). the second digit is stored in the ten's place (`place == 10`). the third is stored in the hundreds place (`place == 100`). ect..

node.contents: thanks, its a good way to reverse a binary number.

astNode.text: thanks, its a good way to reverse a binary number.

node.contents: Don't output each digit as you find them. Build your output incrementally and then print it at the end.

astNode.text: Don't output each digit as you find them. Build your output incrementally and then print it at the end.

elements.contents: public static void main(String[] args) { int num = 0; int temp = 0; Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in); num = sc.nextInt(); int place = 1; int output = 0; while(num != 0) { temp = num % 2; num = num / 2; output += (place*temp); place *=10; } System.out.print(""+output); }

units.rawText: public static void main(String[] args) { int num = 0; int temp = 0; Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in); num = sc.nextInt(); int place = 1; int output = 0; while(num != 0) { temp = num % 2; num = num / 2; output += (place*temp); place *=10; } System.out.print(""+output); }

node.contents: You may need to modify this to handle large or negative numbers.
